Hi,I read some comments about the movie and the lesbian comments,I personally think you narrow minded people get your minds out off the gutter!!!! the movie is wonderful and you people have blown me away with your comments.Please tell me why everything has to contain or be about sex. I believe the story is innocent and shows young people how a real friendship should be.and I'm not gay!!!and i don't believe people look for that in every movie,it is an honest and down to earth movie. so grow up people!!!!!!!!!My husband and i let our girls watch the movie to show them what friendship is all about.I hope my girls have a friends like Idgie and Ruth are.Life is to short to worry about if people r straight or gay.The writer is a great story teller.i think some people who have watched the movie like i have will see that life is great when you have friends and family around to support you,as Idgie and her family and the town supported Ruth and her baby.so please when watching a movie listen for the message and keep your minds on the story and not on sex maybe you can enjoy a movie and get the plot off it.please try to watch it without the awful judgment.

reviews.review_title: This story hooks you from the beginning, and doesn't let go.
reviews.content: I missed this film when it was released.  What a pleasant surprise to watch it and discover it is timeless.  One can enjoy it without the 'dating' that often it prevalent in movies, such as being able to instantly tell a movie is from 'the 80's', or 'the 70's'.  This is a truly enjoyable, entertaining movie; it 'hooks' you into the storyline from the beginning, and doesn't let go.  The actors are so pleasurable to watch, and are consummate professionals in their craft.  Kathy Bates adds comic relief to an otherwise dramatic story.  Chris O'Donnell has a very memorable cameo appearance. Jessica Tandy is just pure 'class.'If you are looking for a very enjoyable classic-type movie; if you enjoy themes other than action and violence, you will enjoy this movie. It is in the same vein as Field of Dreams, or currently - Blast From The Past and Frequency.  This movie will hold its own for years to come.

Forget the endless tide of quick-fix Chicken Soup books; this is REAL soul food.  In fact, I always put on a few pounds just from the cinematography! Jessica Tandy was one of the all-time greats (several years after her death she is still sorely missed), and as usual, Parker and Masterson are perfectly poured, measure for measure, into their beautifully real characters.  Bates' performance here really put her among the ranks, too. Backed up by a rich soundtrack and other aesthetic semi-tangibles, this kind of delicious dish is appreciable in every respect, even for a picky vegetarian like myself.

I remember when I saw this movie, a couple of years ago. Then I didn't have much to say about the film. But here the other night, I sat down, all by myself and watched it. And I have to say, I was impressed. Such a beautiful story. It is sad, but it makes you laugh too. I'm going to buy this movie, and I'll read the book too. I just hope we can see more movies like this, in the future. 10 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Sentiment, Soap Opera, A Dash of Comedy, and a Gallon of Gloss
reviews.content: Fannie Flag's interesting novel gets a gallon of gloss in this very Hollywood movie clearly created with a female audience in mind. The result is a well performed but occasionally uneasy mixture of sentiment, comedy and soap opera.In terms of story, the film operates on two levels. An increasingly frustrated middle aged woman living in Alabama (Bates) examine her life and finds it sadly lacking--but by chance she makes the acquaintance of a nursing home resident (Tandy) whose stories of the past encourage the woman to take charge of her life. The stories she tells are shown through flashback, and concern two depression-era women (Mary Louise Parker and Mary Stuart Masterson) who owned and operated a ramshackle diner in a small hard-times town called whistle stop.The present-day story emphasizes comedy while the depression-era story tends more toward soap opera elements, and the two stories sometimes prove an uneasy mix. A great fuss is often made over the implied lesbian relationship between the two leads in the depression-era story, but I myself find this more in the eye of the beholder than in the actual film; it rather depends on how you read the characters.Much of the film is enjoyable, particularly in its performances with Bates a standout. The dreamy quality in which the depression-era story is presented is also nicely done. But the action is sometimes slow and the tone is both predictable and manipulative; I can almost hear the director telling me "laugh now; cry now" as the film progresses. Enjoyable for one, perhaps even two viewings, but not a film to which I greatly care to return--I'll take the more interesting novel instead.Gary F. Taylor, aka GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviews.review_title: Decent movie propelled by strong women
reviews.content: Despite its obvious tear-jerker ambitions (the staging of which could definitely use more subtlety), "Fried Green Tomatoes" succeeds because of its characters and their relationships.These are people I wanted to hang around with, be a tourist in their lives for just a little longer. All four of the lead actresses do a fine job in this film (Kathy Bates is always a winner), but I mean more specifically Parker and Masterson. Their story is the heart of the movie, and their closeness is what really kept my attention. I was too young back in '92, but adult eyes can clearly see the obvious gay subtext - more importantly, I wish the film wasn't so coy about it.This takes place in the pre-war deep south, so you have a general idea who the villains are, and the film doesn't waste time beating around the bush; racism permeates like the humidity. But on the whole, I enjoyed these two hours in Alabama, and it's thanks to these good-hearted characters.

It's just a bunch of self-contained scenes involving this woman at a hospital telling a younger woman stories of two women in the 1920's-30's being close friends and opening a cafe that sells fried green tomatoes. The present tense scenes feel irrelevant to the flashbacks. There's no real story with a beginning, middle and end. It just meanders and doesn't lead to much.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies I have seen!
reviews.content: I love this movie, I watch it over and over! It is a really funny tale, and i rate it a 10! This movie has the good and bad times, and really paints a picture of the old days in the west. The cast is perfect, and is enjoyable. My faviorte scene is so funny, that it would spiol it if I told you what happened. If anyone rates this below an 8 they must have have a bad taste for the best movies! I recommed this movie to all ages, and if you ever want a laugh or need to cheer up watch this and be smiling and laughing for hours. This is sad in parts, and really has some depressing scenes, but the scenes that stick in my mind our the funniest ones. :)

Predictable and comfortable if you are a mild feminist. The guys are stereotypes - so I guess that means there is some truth in their actions, but not all guys are like this - the movie is obviously feel good for the ladies and thats ok but us guys may get a bit bored.The sound was pretty poor which did not help following the narrative.
A story about love and friendship. About a small American town, about people, kindness and secrets.A must see.

reviews.review_title: Ranks as a greatest of All-Time!!!!
reviews.content: This movie is an excellent, must-see!  I think the acting is wonderful and the plot is superb!!!!  As usual, Kathy Bates pulled off another great acting job and the late Jessica Tandy is as great as ever!Even my young nieces and nephews enjoyed the movie -- especially the food fight between Idgie and Ruth at the Whistle Stop Cafe!It is a heart-warming, clean movie about one of the most cherished gifts ever:  friends!  Ninny Threadgood even stated that at the end of the movie!Larry S.

Great movie with a female cast and that over in how the late Jessica Tandy as a fun loving nursing home resident and Kathy Bates is a unhappy, overweight mild mannered housewife who's husband does not want anything to do with her.And that she finds independence and being strong as that Tandy's character tells the story of two friends, Mary Stuart Masterson and Mary Louise Parker in the. Southern town in the 1920-1930's there. In the Jim Crow law days.How that they made sure their friendship work despite what was facing them. Still such a great movie there.

reviews.review_title: Saucy saute with good acting to boot
reviews.content: Fried Green Tomatoes might be considered a chick flick. Well, so be it and more power to it. Go ahead and be ready to laugh, and also to tear up over some of the scenes. This is a well-acted, well directed, and enjoyable film in the solid time-honored tradition of totally watchable Grade B movies. Some of the characters portrayed are people a viewer can get to know for a few hours and really sympathize with. Other's behavior you can get mad at. You might even want to express a little outrage at some behavior portrayed. Enjoy it. The film has its flaws, but for the most part is one the sensitive and discerning viewer can see more that once and be happier with than much of the real trivial tripe that passes for film these days. And to be perfectly honest, it's better than the book.

I finally saw this movie. After all the great reviews I've read/heard, I must say I'm unbelievably disappointed.First of all, I couldn't believe how one-dimensional the characters were - they seemed like plot points rather than actual people. Wild and Crazy Idgy is wild and crazy, Shy and Submissive Ruth is shy and submissive, Mean Abusive Husband is mean and abusive. The characterizations seemed to go no further than that...how am I supposed to sympathize/identify with these people when they have no depth at all? What's worse, this movie was so predictable and contrived, and I feel like I knew exactly what was going to happen as soon as each scene began. The way they kept getting that shot of the cauldron and everyone kept mentioning how good the barbecue was after Mean Abusive Husband was missing? Come ON, a post-it note could figure out what was going on. And is it wrong that I almost laughed at the cliché, tear-jerky, practically-required-by-law death toward the end? I'm not here to only complain - I must say that I found the segments with Evelyn to be very engaging, much more interesting than the flashbacks. Maybe this would have been better if it were two different movies?No, it wasn't the worst movie I've ever seen, but I really don't think it deserves all the rave reviews it has on this site. Plus I think I'm extra resentful of the fact that, just because I'm a woman, I'm expected to fall hook line and sinker for this kind of dull mediocrity.

This film touched me in so many ways that I cannot begin to praise it. It is about friendship and family.  It is about knowing what true love really is, the unconditional love we all search for.  I like this film for the way I feel about myself, it helps you think about all of your relationships and why they are so important to you. And it is even a little bit of history, it shows what it was like to live in the South in the early part of this century, and since that century is now almost over, it is cool to reflect upon the beginning of it. Enjoy the movie :-) PS The food isn't bad either!!!!

As a native of Birmingham, Alabama, I thought they did a very good job of recreating Irondale. I would almost swear that parts of this film were actually filmed there. Also, I can remember when Fannie Flagg co-hosted a local morning show in Birmingham. I used to watch it every morning while I was getting ready for school. She was also a weather forecaster for our local TV station. She sure came a long way since then.Not much changed in Alabama between the twenties and the time I grew up there, and seeing this movie brought back memories of all those good home-cooked Southern meals. Fried okra, fried green tomatoes, fried squash, and good old Alabama barbecue. Alabama has the best barbecue in the nation.Folks in Alabama take their food seriously, and they also take friendships seriously. I guess that's why it is so easy to read things into Idgey and Ruth's relationship that may not be there. (Lesbianism? In Alabama? In the 20s and 30s? Get real, people!!!) Anyone even suspected of such behavior in Alabama back then would have been unceremoniously lynched. So, let's try not to read too much into Idgie's and Ruth's friendship, huh? Evelyn's and Ninny's friendship is very moving for anyone who has ever had a friend that changed them, that gave them the strength to keep going when all hope seemed to be lost. And I think posters are being a little too hard on her husband. Ed seems like essentially a good man. He just falls into the same trap that most of us men fall into. We allow ourselves to get too caught up in our own little worlds to pay much mind to what makes our wives ache and thrill. (Come on, fellows, we're all guilty of that sometimes. Be honest.) Throughout the movie, Ed shows that he is devoted to his wife, even if he is totally oblivious to what is going on in her life.This movie reminds me of STAND BY ME, because it makes you want to laugh and cry at the same time and it gives you a snapshot of a time and place that is gone forever. A gem of a film. 8 out of 10.

This film is on par with the best of modern day movies such as Raging Bull,Being There, American Beauty,Tender Mercies, Lost in Translation,Heathers,Ghost World...... Some of my buddies rag on me calling it a "chick flick", but it is as good any movie of the past 25 years.I have to watch it every time it airs. I just missed half of a football game because I kept jumping back to Tomatoes! Great screenplay (and novel).And what a great cast!Well I see that my comment was not long enough so I will say how doggone hot Mary Stuart Masterson and Mary Louise Parker are!!! have they ever been anything that wasn't good, and I mean I even liked Bad Girls, or whatever it was called, with Masterson. Well I have now typed enough lines, but now I want to talk about Masterson's great smile for ten more lines.

I think I have seen the movie at least 5 or more times. I love it. You see something each time you watch it that you missed the first time. My friend and I also went to the Whistle Cafe Stop Cafe in Juliette, Ga and had lunch. It was terrific. We had Peach Cobbler for desert and we could have gone back for more. I bought candy and soap in the Honeycomb Store and today I ordered some more. The soap is so nice you can smell it all over my house. The candy is awesome. Take time to see the movie. Be sure to visit the Whistle Stop Cafe in Juliette, Ga and to also stop in at the Honeycomb and what ever other stores are open. I love places like this that are still there for others to see. It makes the movie seem even more real.

There are some movies that I may recommend to everybody, and that don't look outdated with time. That is for sure one nice example. The screenplay is a great adaptation of the novel, the actors are terrific, Jessica Tandy and Kathy Bates in their best (what is a very high level) and Chris O'Donnell in a surprising remarkable participation. Impossible to don't get touched by this film. After 23 years it is such a good job that it still express its value as a masterpiece. The development of the plot with the flashbacks and storytelling was very original and completely adequate. Considering so much trash we see being blockbusters in current theaters, I do emphasize that looking backward we can find some stories that no one should miss.
Excellent story telling and acting. It was interesting from start and Kathy Bates played amazingly her character. It is really a feel good movie and makes this movie. It surprised me in a good way.

My favorite movie of all time. I have seen it more time than I care to admit. The only thing I can add to the above comments, is that you should watch the movie again, then read the book and watch it once more. You will enjoy the movie far more after that. The book describes the relationship between Idgie and Ruth in a heartwarming and loving way. The acceptance of Ruth by Idgie's parents and other family members is remarkably described with love and delicacy of their relationship. While their relationship is definitely lesbian, even the most homophobic person on earth would enjoy the book, and could not fault Fanny Flagg in the book's handling of their love for each other, especially in that era.

I just watched this film for the 3rd or 4th time and each time it touches me to the very depth of my heart. It is a perfectly made film, flawlessly acted, brilliantly written and directed. More of the actors, and the director, should have received Oscar nominations. This is a film about life and all of its elements: family, tragedy, loss, racism, physical abuse, emotional abuse, abuse of power, marriage, spirituality, but most of all the spirit of love and deep, abiding friendship that both conflicts and resonates deeply through all of the conjoined characters, their lives, and their purpose. Few films will touch you as deeply as Fried Green Tomatoes, its profound message one you will carry with you every day of your life, with everyone you know. This is one of the best films ever made.

Was spurred to write a comment after reading the unfair trashing of this very enjoyable film by another user.The point of the film is to show the strength of friendship and I think it does so very well. The characters are endearing and funny, and well portrayed by the actors. I would recommend this film to anyone who wants a light film that leaves you with warm fuzzy feelings at the end of it.

reviews.review_title: The film addresses themes such as gender violence, homosexual relationships, gerontophobia and feminism through a strong friendship in a rediscovery story
reviews.content: Every week, Evelyn (Kathy Bates) visits her husband's aunt Ed (Gailard Sartain) in the hospital, but is not welcomed by the patient. In a moment of sadness, she ends up meeting Ninny Threadgoode (Jessica Tandy), an 83-year-old lady who loves to tell stories. In these weekly conversations, Ninny starts to tell you the story of Ruth (Mary-Louise Parker) and Idgie (Mary Stuart Masterson), two girls who built a strong friendship in the 1920s, causing controversy in the city, mainly for treating blacks well."Fried Green Tomatoes" is a delicate film, which subtly addresses some potentially controversial subjects. Subtlety, by the way, is the word that best defines Jon Avnet's direction, who leads the narrative with elegance from the foreground of the film, which refers to the murder of Frank Bennett (Nick Searcy), with the truck being pulled out of the water. The director shows competence in composing beautiful shots, like the one in which Buddy Threadgoode (Chris O'Donnell), Idgie and Ruth walk over the dam's waters or the tense shot in which Idgie talks to her boss in the cafe while the members of Ku Klux Klan, led by Bennett, approach the window. Note also the perfect composition of the shot in which Ruth reveals the black eye, surprising the viewer when she turns her face to answer her husband's call, revealing the problems she had in that troubled relationship.Certainly, one of the highlights of the feature, the screenplay written by Fannie Flagg and Carol Sobieski, based on a book by Fannie Flagg, demonstrates courage not only by addressing such an intimate relationship between two women, but because it does not mask the disgusting prejudice that prevailed at the time, when society treated blacks as mere servants destined to serve them in the best way. In addition, the narrative structure of "Fried Green Tomatoes" abuses flashbacks, which in this case work well, because of Tandy's engaging narration and Debra Neil-Fisher's dynamic montage, which alternates between past and present at a delicious pace. And if there is clearly a courageous homosexual subtext in the friendship between Ruth and Idgie, the film never openly answers the question (which is consistent with the period in which the story takes place, when prejudice was even more ingrained in people), preferring to indicate subtly the feeling they both had through small gestures, like when Ruth tells Idgie that it was the best birthday of her life and gives her friend a kiss. Many years later, in front of a jury and the local society, she would declare that Idgie was her best friend and that she loved her. Idgie, on the other hand, was more spontaneous, not hesitating, for example, to snatch Ruth away from her violent husband, even threatening him with death.Obviously, the excellent performance of Parker and Masterson is vital for the success of that relationship and both do very well, showing excellent chemistry (a highlight for the scene in which they play with food, with a clear sexual connotation). Precisely for this reason, when we see Ruth preparing for death and Idgie, emotional, repeating the story of the lake that ended up in Georgia, it is very difficult to hold back the tears, precisely because we believe in the true love they felt. The viewer knows that Idgie is losing more than a friend at that moment, she is losing the most important person in her life. And even the distant shot of Avnet demonstrates a deep respect for the moment, as if the director were watching from afar that sad farewell, reflected even in the obscure photography of the scene. Parker still stands out in the scene where he talks about the prayers that were of no use to save his mother, accurately conveying the distress that Ruth felt for not having reacted as she should, also causing Evelyn to change, who then reacts to the provocations of two women in a parking lot. From that moment on, Evelyn started to think more about herself and less about her husband, starting to take care of her health and change everything she disliked, like the bedroom wall that blocked the passage of sunlight.And it should be noted that, like Parker and Masterson, Tandy and Bates also establish an excellent connection in their delightful conversations, with emphasis on the touching dialogue about menopause and about Ninny's son, where the talent of the two actresses stands out. From the audience - notice Tandy's emotion when remembering her son who died and her touching joy when imagining that soon, according to her faith, she will be able to find him again. Kathy Bates is absolutely entertaining as Evelyn, gradually changing her behavior over the course of the film, peaking when she reacts to taunts in a parking lot and then storming into the hospital, pouring out all the years of repression and anguish. The difference between this Evelyn and the woman who blindly followed the tips on the course for wives is striking, wrapping herself in paper to surprise her husband, in a tragically funny scene, which exposes how much that relationship was deteriorated - something that is also evident when the husband he doesn't even pay attention, preferring to watch whatever game is on television. In fact, even the couple's physical form shows that the concern to please the other has long been in the past.But the big change in Evelyn's life was yet to come - and the way she looked at the cafe, feeling the wind blowing and imagining the noise of the train at the beginning of the film, already indicated the importance that that place would have in her life, without that she would never need to step inside him. And the motivating agent of this change is Ninny, played by Jessica Tandy, who is even more charming than usual in the skin of the lady full of passion for life, who renews Evelyn's (and the viewer's) spirit with her direct and optimistic way of talking. Look at almost every situation and challenge of our journey. So, when we see a depressed Ninny looking at her old house, sadness is inevitable. But even this moment of weakness makes Ninny great, showing that she is vulnerable like any of us, but still, she is always looking for a new way to smile. And rounding out the cast, Nick Searcy gives a one-dimensional performance as Frank Bennett, a man who seems to live only to torment Ruth's life. Of course, the fact that the story is told by Ninny attenuates this Manichaeism in the script, as it is clearly her view of that man.As well as the nature of the relationship between Ruth and Idgie, there are other situations in "Fried Green Tomatoes" that allow for different interpretations. This is not the case of Bennett's murder, which even maintains suspense during a good part of the narrative, but reveals the true story in its third act, illustrating how the evidence does not always lead to the absolute truth. This is the case, however, with Idgie's identity, one of those situations that each spectator can interpret in her own way. Purposely, the script never openly says whether Ninny was Idgie or not, spreading some situations throughout the narrative that may indicate Idgie as Ninny's distant past. For example, Ninny talks about moments in the lives of Ruth and Idgie that only the two of them could know, she says that she liked Buddy when he was attracted to Ruth (and clearly Idgie was jealous of her brother) and, mainly, honey and the note left on Ruth's grave suggest that she passed by after leaving the hospital. But this is just an assumption, as the film prefers to leave both possibilities open, which is always interesting, as it fuels discussions.And in addition to the beautiful framing, director Jon Avnet shows competence in directing remarkable scenes, such as Buddy's shocking death. Apparently harmless (we see Buddy trying to catch the hat that flies lightly over the tracks), the tone of the scene suddenly changes when the boy's foot gets tangled in the tracks, but the viewer keeps a thread of hope that in the final moment Buddy will escape. Unfortunately, this is not what happens, and the next shot confirms the tragedy. It is also worth mentioning the beautiful scene in which Ruth and Idgie throw food to the poor from inside the train, with the faces of those hopeful children begging for help, punctuated by one of the rare appearances on the soundtrack by Thomas Newman.It is impossible not to be moved by the moment when Evelyn, believing that her friend has died, attacks the nursing home nurse, who, insensibly, was already tearing up the roses glued to the wall, which the lady loved so much, preparing the room to the next number in the property statistics. A beautiful scene that conveys a strong message, unfortunately, increasingly current. Love and gratitude, which lead the woman to take responsibility for the future of the lady, so fragile and devalued in society, responsible for her decisive change in attitude. The train goes on its way, the quietest passenger, the one who stays in the corner, whom nobody appreciates, can completely change the course of his life.Time has been generous with Fried Green Tomatoes (1991), one of the most talked about films of the 1990s, which continues to be engaging in its episodic flashback structure while still delivering a critically current message about feminism. The film addresses themes such as gender violence, homosexual relationships, gerontophobia and feminism through a strong friendship, and why not say love, between two women is the common thread of Evelyn's rediscovery story, which through Ninny's will to live find your own happiness. And if Ninny's joy is contagious to Evelyn, the optimism of "Fried Green Tomatoes" is also contagious to the viewer, who leaves renewed in the face of so much desire to live and be happy.

reviews.review_title: fried green TOMATOES!! (is a good movie!)
reviews.content: This is quite a good movie! we are watching it at school and we all thought it was going to be a massive old 1990s "chick flick" but it was actually really good! Really good actors and actresses and has a great use of flashbacks (says my English teacher:P) and i think it is one of those movies that u can watch over and over again and not get sick of it. I am just filling up space here!! so anyway we are told the story by Ninnie the old lady, and she tells the life of Alabama people in a little town and lots of things happen - sad and happy but the endings the best bit! The accents are really cool too. so as i am coming to the end of this "comment" i shall bid u farewell so go and watch it!!!

Fried Green Tomatoes is a solid film that is able to create a vibe that feels warm and nostalgic in a way that I can't really explain. Typically I don't have a lot of affection for this time period in the deep south, but this movie makes it work for me. I think part of my enjoyment comes from the fact that it focuses almost entirely on such a remarkably sweet friendship between these two women (one could argue there's more than a friendship there, but the movie certainly never commits to that being the case.) In fact, the makeshift family they create is 100% loveable and warms your heart. It's hard to avoid getting emotionally invested in the story of Idgie and Ruth. I am 100% convinced that, even though this isn't exactly my type of movie, this would still be quite high on my chart of favorite films if these flashbacks were the whole movie.Unfortunately, Fried Green Tomatoes is the tale of two movies. I don't have any objections to Kathy Bates or Jessica Tandy. They are delightful actresses and I don't have a big problem with the idea of these two women creating an unlikely friendship, but I don't think it clicks at all as a framing device. The idea that these stories are inspiring the change in Bates' character doesn't make a ton of sense to me. The flashback story being told isn't particularly about girl power, and the whole "Towanda" thing almost feels tacked on just to have a verbal shortcut to force audiences to believe these 2 stories are connected. I won't even get into the weird implications made by the final scene in the movie, that are a bit disturbing. I don't hate the Bates-Tandy film, I just don't like what it does to the Masterson-Parker film. Fried Green Tomatoes is OK, but with the potential to be better.

reviews.review_title: Unsettling At Times But Has Some Sweet Tones
reviews.content: "Fried Green Tomatoes" is a juxtapose of an emotional tearful drama with some light-heart comical moments that has similar veins to more superior and less manipulative films like "Steel Magnolias" and "Crimes of the Heart".What makes this movie not live up to its expectations was that they try to cover too much which at the result gets very little accomplished. Sure we understand that friendship and bonding is a very important commodity. It has a habit of pushing the envelop so much that the story it's trying to tell never fully settles and then we are left confused. The relationships portrayed here tend to lack in being believable and that we just have to take it like a pinch of salt, though the fans of this movie might be more accepting.The performers are what holds this movie together and they do everything in their power to keep us intrigued as they pour it to its audience splendidly. Their acting chops are so powerful they will get their message across even if they have to go a bit-over-the-top to get its message across. This could be bothersome to others, but by the end, the morals will etched in stone.Under the direction of Jon Avnet, "Fried Green Tomatoes" starred two hot actresses at the time. What I mean by hot I'm talking about Kathy Bates who won an Academy Award for her role in "Misery" and Jessica Tandy who won the Oscar for Best Actress for her role in "Driving Miss Daisy". In this movie, Bates plays the role of a lamented, middle-aged Evelyn Couch, a midwife who's not pleased about her marriage and her life in Birmingham, Alabama as her only source of comfort is consuming candy bars. Tandy plays the role of an aging nursing home resident named Ninny Threadgoode who becomes friends with Evelyn as she communicates with her by telling her an extended anecdote that has some connection to her past.Bates and Tandy earn a myriad of awards and accolades for their respected performances which is set in the present, but many flashbacks to Ninny's past also comes into affect as the story progresses.Though they were still unknown at the time, Mary Stuart Masterson does a wonderful job as Idgie Threadgoode her supposed sister-in-law, a tomboyish type who comes to the rescue of her friend Ruth Jamison (Mary-Louise Parker) who's in an abusive relationship with her husband, Frank Bennett (Nick Searcy) while also confronting other issues like racism, the KKK,male chauvinism, segregation and being framed as Sheriff Grady Kilgore (Gary Basaraba) for Frank's death only to later drop the charges against her.Parker who at the time was only known for her role in the AIDS themed movie "Longtime Companion" was effective in her performance as the long-suffering Ruth who found comfort with Idgie and when she's had enough of Frank's wrath, takes her belongings and helps run the business Idgie operates in the abandoned town of Whistle Stop, Alabama.Although this is based from the 1987 novel "Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistle Shop Cafe" by Fannie Flagg, she also gets credit for the screenplay as well as from Avnet and Carol Sobieski. This was the directorial debut for Avnet who beforehand served as a producer for "Risky Business" (with Tom Cruise) and also directed the 1986 TV movie "Between Two Women" starring Farrah Fawcett and Coleen Dewhurst.What "Rambling Rose" succeeded that "Fried Green Tomatoes" failed was the lack of handling the writers and directors had on the script. Avnet loosely gives Bates the green light to overdo it with the melodrama, especially at the beginning, the script is offering its audience scenes that weren't a necessity let alone saturated with dishonesty. There's the courtroom scene that is at times a bit ridiculous to watch and the outcome is predictable as our heroes actually to the courts and the officials just give in. Then we get an ending that is really hard to watch as Ninny explains the whole gruesome way Frank died. And then we are led to believe that someone is dead only to reveal, that they're really not.Though not the worst movie ever made, Bates eventually tones down in the latter scenes showcasing she can be entertaining to watch and can be subtle when given the chance. Tandy though advanced in age is still astoundingly effective and shows that her age will not slow her down. Even though she's been acting since the golden age of cinema, her later years have been the best. Through all of its red herrings, there is still plenty to like about this movie.

Do you have comfort shows or media? Whenever I am overtired, too tired to think or just need a brain vacation, I retreat into favourite movies an TV series. This is one of those. I fell in love with this movie when it was first released (1991), bought and wore out the VHS tape (how we "streamed" in the olden days), bought the DVD, even bought and read the book (Fannie Flagg writes beautiful books). The casting for this is amazing, Kathy Bates and Jessica Tandy (who was nominated for an Oscar in this role) forging an unlikely but transformative friendship in the present and Mary Stuart Masterson and Mary-Louise Parker as Idgie and Ruth, the relationship at the heart of Ninny's story within the story, then add Cicely Tyson - Perfection! I didn't realize, until I read the book, what a brave adventure it was to take this book to screen. It bravely took on many themes that challenged the norms of the time with grace and power without alienating the audience from the deep emotional bonds of the characters. Of course, I love everything about this film and give this film a 10 (perfect) out of 10. {Drama with humour}

reviews.review_title: They Don't Make Films Like This Anymore
reviews.content: They don't make em like this anymore. The acting was brilliant and the story captivated you about the old South. The film reminded me of a Saturday morning in the park. Wonderfully refreshing and light while at the same time caked with deep meaning. I enjoyed Jessica Tandy's performance. In fact, the entire cast was brilliant. Hollywood needs to make more of these types of films. To be honest, I've lost my love for films about 3 years ago. Haven't watched too many since and I'm 40 years old. Films today remind me of fast food - no effort was made at all in making them. Hopefully, they'll hire executives in Hollywood with something more than a high school education.

To me this movie was nothing special. It is a failed dramady with an easy to follow formula and a very melodramatic plot. Did anybody seriously not see the ending coming? While people might say that the predictability might add to the movie's "charms", I disagree. i doubt it was intentional. The Evelyn Couch story line was utterly pointless except to give the story a reason to be told. The filmmakers tried to add humor to the Couch's situation but it failed miserably. The overload of drama made each "twist" less exciting than the one before. It failed to make me cry, I cry in pretty much everything, and I couldn't care less what happened to any character at the end. While Jessica Tandy was phenomenal, the only true shining performance, the rest of the cast fell flat. Most flashback movies don't work. They don't bring the story to life and it is very distracting to go from one time period to another. Very few films have ever made that work, and this is not one of them. What attempted to be a great cinematic experience simply turned into a pretentious, overrated dud.

Directed by Jon Avnet. Starring Mary Stuart Masterson, Mary-Louise Parker, Kathy Bates, Jessica Tandy, Gary Basaraba, Gailard Sartain, Cicely Tyson, Stan Shaw, Chris O'Donnell, Tim Scott, Richard Riehle, Nick Searcy, Raynor Scheine. (PG-13)While visiting her husband's aunt in a nursing home, dissatisfied housewife Bates makes the acquaintance of an elderly woman (Tandy) who tells her a Depression-era story of racial hostility, spousal abuse, murder, and the intimate "friendship" between Masterson and Parker. The dominant flashback storyline is conventional and predictable and succumbs to cheap tearjerking tactics by the end, but is still far and away the more engaging aspect of the film; the contemporary framing sequences are well-acted by Tandy and Bates (despite the latter being a caricature that develops into a different caricature), but are also cutesy and obvious. Film coasts on the appeal of the leading ladies and their friendships, as well as its universal message grilled in barbecue-scented nostalgia. Directorial debut for Avnet; based on a novel by Fannie Flagg.61/100

reviews.review_title: A nice film despite it's flaws
reviews.content:
In the present day, Kathy Bates, a fairly unhappy housewife, has a meet-cute with nursing home resident Jessica Tandy who starts telling her the story of:
Her relative Mary Stuart Masterson who favours men's clothes and bawdy pursuits and develops a pretty extreme affection for Mary-Louise Parker, who marries violent lout Nick Searcy. Masterson whisks Parker away from her husband and they live together at a café that serves the titular dish.The film adaptation of Fannie Flagg's extremely popular book is pretty damn good except for a few issues. The relationship between Masterson and Parker is very very obviously coded as a lesbian relationship, but it wasn't coded in the book and doesn't feel like it needs to be here. It has the issue a lot of book adaptations have in feeling very condensed. A lot of issues and plot threads come up with no time to resolve them, making the whole thing feel a bit slight.But, the core of the film is good. Masterson and Parker are clearly brave, non-conformists in an time and place where conformity is overvalued, and having their story inspire Bates to stand up for her own happiness is ... well, very nice. It's a difficult film to dislike. I general stand for any movie that features lesbian cannibals, especially if they are played by Oscar caliber performers.

This movie took me "back home" to such wonderful memories of Alabama/Georgia. It should have won at least ten Academy Awards. The casting was perfection right down to the children's parts. When George first stirred that pot "the next mornin'" I screamed then - I already knew the secret was in the sauce. If I'm ever in a nursing home I pray to have a friend like Evelyn Couch. Fannie Flagg hit the peak with her book and kept the movie true to the story. The scenes and details of those days in the south were so good you could smell the barbecue. Thanks to this movie I can say that I voted myself into the Tawanda club and have stayed there ever since!

reviews.review_title: The story tell us about one of life's most important treasures.
reviews.content: Thru flash backs we are taken back to south in the 1930s . A minor plot is in the present day of the movie's production. The trips to the "president day" do not distract us from the story set in the 1930s. Yet we always want to return to the main plot of the1930s. A moving and memorial movie.

FRIED GREEN TOMATOES is certainly a movie that some people will enjoy. I enjoyed some things about it, but overall found it boring and stale. The truth is that it's a film about women for women.So as a man, there wasn't that much here for me. I know it's widely considered to be a classic, and it's good enough, I suppose. The acting is quite good, but I think you really have to be a woman in order to get everything out of this film that there is to be had. Recommend for women only.

Movie blends friendships between persons of different races, while outside world still racist and bigoted. Women got right to vote in 1920s, and in urban areas were doing the Charleston, smoking and driving fast cars. In Whistle Stop, the days went slowly and down-homish. Cicily Tyson sweet in this movie. Very loyal to her friends. Jessica Tandy -- what a classic sweetie. People helping each other in this movie; caring about each other. These characters were not trying to save the world or worry about the starving children on the other side of the world. This was a time warp of place and action, a microcosm of a lost world that once existed in gently remembered splendor. No one wealthy or living in mansions. It was an old timey rural area. People did what they could to get through the days. Looks like they were all generally pretty poor.

This movie was so good, I have seen it countless times and every time I watch every second of it. Some people think this movie was about two women in love, maybe it was, but the real story line is finding in someone the love that we all yearn to feel. Many have said horrible things about Idgie and Ruths love but I think its more than that, its knowing that you have found your soul mate, whether it is a same sex or opposite sex soul mate. Don't focus on something that is not really important in this movie because that is not what the director and the writers want you to focus on, its the meaning of life and how life goes on. I suggest those who have not read the book to read asap. It really is wonderful

reviews.review_title: Imogene "Idgie" Threadgoode (Mary Stuart Masterson) and Ruth Jamison (Mary-Louise Parker)
reviews.content: Favorite Scene withImogene "Idgie" Threadgoode (Mary Stuart Masterson) - The Very Hilarious Food Fight Scene between her and Ruth. I Loved how Idgie went from Very Rebellious to Very Responsible.Ruth Jamison (Mary-Louise Parker) - The Very Hilarious Food Fight Scene between her and Idgie. I Loved how Ruth went from Very Rigid and Very By-The-Book to Very Daring. She Truly was an Angel On Earth.BTW #1, I Loved, Loved, Loved this Movie!!! I Loved the Settings and the 3 Time Periods! - The 20's - 30's and the 80's. BTW #2, Ninny was Really Idgie. BTW #3, I Loved, Loved, Loved Kathy Bates (Evelyn Couch) and Jessica Tandy (Ninny Threadgoode/Idgie Threadgoode)!!! BTW #4, Towanda!!!

I am a woman, and this "women's movie" sickened me.  "Fried Green Tomatoes" tends to be admired by radical feminists because the women in it are portrayed as loving, sensitive, mutually supportive, and oppressed by men--and the men in it are portrayed, of course, as evil, stupid, or both. It is a travesty.The ending is nothing short of filth--a plot twist that is inhuman and monstrous, but which fans of the movie seem to regard as uplifting.  That says it all.

I know that this movie was after Driving Miss Daisy I really can't balance THAT movie and to balance Fried Green Tomatoes. But I have to say that Friend Green Tomatoes IS Jessica Tandy's best 90's movie every before she passed in '94. I must say that F.G.T. is my all time favorite movie with Jessica Tandy staring (next by Driving Miss Daisy and also *batteries not included*) and many, many more. But still for staring Friend Green Tomatoes with Kathy Bates, Mary Stuart Masterson, Mary-Louise Parker, Stan Shaw & several other faces I knew; I must say that THIS movie has to overcome "Driving Miss Daisy" but it's still 10 stars for this movie and 10 stars for Driving Miss Daisy because Jessica Tandy was always the best actress for all time; she was always wonderful, caring, loving, and funny. Driving Miss Daisy was my favorite because Morgan Freeman Is ALSO and still is also an all time favorite actor. But all and all Friend Green Tomatoes, I need to buy that movie (I can't believe that I don't have it yet).

Here's masterful work that imbues you to it through its realism. A housewife who is unhappy with her life befriends an old lady in a nursing home and is enthralled by the tales she tells of people she used to know. This is the kind of film that proves that a small story can be much more meaningful than a larger one. The only thing that keeps it afloat is the sensitivity of the relationships. I found the acting to be sensational, the dialogue incredible and the director's abilities to be up to par and then some. I really like this type of film, as it reminds me of French movies where it's more about the characters and their environment.

Evelyn Couch (Kathy Bates) subsists on Krispy Kreme donuts and low self-esteem. Her fat slug of a husband is oblivious to the attention she so desperately craves; he would rather plop in front of the set to watch his baseball game, and wolf down the wonderful meals she dutifully prepares. Soon, Evelyn befriends Mrs. Threadgoode, an octogenarian woman living her last days at a retirement home. Through their friendship, two beautiful stories begin to unravelone takes place in 1930s Alabama, and one in the present. Through this parallel-storytelling technique, Evelyn comes to realize the beauty of love and develops a healthy perseverance towards personal fulfillment.If you haven't seen this little movie, by all means sit a spell and share it with your best friends. There is nothing more soothing than experiencing the sights and sounds of a bygone country summer: rocking slowly inside screened-in porches, the song of crickets and katydids, eating southern-fried chicken, and drinking ice-cold sarsaparilla soda right out of the bottle. Don't be fooled, though. The film also has its share of heavy-handed yet serious drama, so be prepared for a truly unique Sunday morning 'barbecue.' Actors Bates and Tandy are fantastic as, respectively, Evelyn and Mrs. Threadgoode. Bates is especially endearing as Evelyn, and Tandyas usualturns in an engagingly eccentric role as the seemingly dotty old biddy with a sensitive heart and a sweet-fillingher character is a walking historical-journal ready to be opened and read. Masterson and Parker, however, lack the sufficient chops to match the superior-quality of the older actresses' thespian-talent.Somehow, Masterson and Parker (playing Depression Era fictional best-friends) are mismatched within essencetheir symbolic (1991) contemporaries. The overall narrative faintly resembles something written by Alice Walker, were Walker an Anglo-Saxon instead of a black novelist.FYI: Author/screenwriter/actress Fannie Flagg was a regular player on the TV game show Match Game.

reviews.review_title: Strong Southern Women in these troubled times.
reviews.content: This film's cinematography and musical score alone make it a worthwhile experience. Both have that almost-unreal-they're-so-perfect quality that give you the good kind of goosebumps.The story is played out so faultlessly by each of the actors in this movie that you're never for one second anything but totally enthralled and engrossed.  The film's main story lines revolve around southern women, in old and modern times, and the bonds of friendship that are at once so tender and so unbreakably strong.  Jessica Tandy's portrayal of Ms. Ninny Threadgood had to be my favorite if forced to choose.  The way she faced life unafraid and with sympathy and humor just warmed your whole being, say nothing of your heart.  But each and every actor in this film brought their very best, and no one disappointed.I'm probably too naive, but the homosexual overtones that several friends of mine said existed in the movie were totally lost on me - perhaps because I'm lucky enough to have a precious few friendships like the ones portrayed here, and there is nothing of the sort in those friendships.  I did read the book only after watching this film, and Ms. Flagg does present a totally different light on that particular subject than is in the movie - I'd recommend both the movie and the book - both are wonderful and thought provoking.

Here's the real summary of the film: The story is a flashback about two women, a butch feminist rescuing a "femme", helpless woman from her racist, abusive Southern husband (is there any other kind?) She kills the husband and feeds the body to unwitting, stupid Southerners as BBQ. haha! Jokes on those stupid Southerners! Happy ending for Hollywood. During the film, the women grow together with grrl power and start their own business (because that's the path to feminine empowerment) and befriend weak men they are able to use to help make them more powerful.If you liked this, then you'll love Thelma and Louise which is a similar type of grrl power film. Another film with a similar theme is the Emma Stone vehicle The Help which features African servants spilling the secrets of privileged white Southern women (which I found funny in retrospect because when Hollywood stars got hacked and had their nude pictures posted on the web, they got all upset about the invasion of privacy.) These films are useful to watch to see the contempt Hollywood has for the working class people that keep them fat and happy.

I read the book 2-3 years before the movie came out. It remains as one of my favorite books. So I was eagerly awaiting the movie although I realized the book was too complex to completely transfer to film. I had high hopes. I was not disappointed. The actors were brilliant. Although I wish more characters from the book had made it into the move. ie: Big Georges wife and I would have loved to see the Naughty-bird/elephant story in the film. It would also given a better insight to Idgie's and Big Georges relationship.If I had not read the book I would have still loved the movie but having read the book I was truly disappointed in the ending of the movie. To lead viewers to believe Ninny was really Idgie is disrespectful of both characters. Ninny was a wonderful character by herself. Everyone who did not read the book must wonder at the story Ninny told Evelyn about her mentally retarded son Alfred. Also If you look closely Jessica Tandy appears as Ninny in one of the cafe scenes. Idgie actually serves her a plant of fried green tomatoes. I also don't believe they actually served pieces of bar-b-qued Frank Bennett to the investigator. I think they just cooked him up with the rest of the meat. At least I like to think so. All in all a wonderful movie but read the book and get a real insight into all the wonderful characters.

reviews.review_title: A true masterpiece of real life in the past.
reviews.content: This movie is one of the best ever made and I truly enjoyed every aspect of it. Even though this movie takes place in the past, I believe it has many topics that are still true to todays society. Such as the importance of love and friendship and the concept of racism. I hope that you are encouraged to see it today if you have not already! It will make you laugh, cry, and beg for more!

"Fried Green Tomatoes" is a down home movie that made me want to live in Alabama (sayin a lot). It is well done, well acted, and a long and complicated book being so skillfully compiled into an entertaining and fastpaced movie really impressed me. I watched in 4 times in five days. Touching, but not too sentimental.

Fried Green Tomatoes is easily one of the best films of the 90's. Kathy Bates and Jessica Tandy give such an outstanding performance. I believe that they should have both defently won oscar's for this.What this film is about is Evelen Couch (Bates). She's an overweight housewife who's marriage isn't going all that well and she has low self esteem. She goes to a nursing home with her husband to meet an old aunt and there she meets Ninny Threadgoode (Tandy) who is a sweet 82 year old optimist. Ninny tells Evelen a story about what happened to people she know many years ago. This is where another story comes into it and it is just as powerful and moving as the other one.Over time Evelen grows more confidence in herself and becomes more happy and she and Ninny become best friends. If you believe that this film doesn't sound like much then you are deeply mistaken. It is such an excellent film.

While the film is technically accomplished, I've never been more disgusted with a film than I was with "FGT".  This horrid offering features the absolute worst kind of pseudo-feminist male bashing claptrap.  As she becomes "empowered", Kathy Bates turns into a horrible person, but we're supposed to admire her!  She threatens to hurt anyone who disagrees with her and yet we're supposed to like her.  I didn't, and I loathe this atrocious piece of trash.  If I could have rated it a "zero" I would - it's a terrible piece of work for which all participants should be ashamed.

reviews.review_title: Kathy Bates is the best thing about this one.
reviews.content: I watched this with a friend the other day and I had a pretty good idea what I was getting myself into. Its written by a woman it stars women and its set in the south. Can you say chick flick.I knew my grandpa loved the movie and considered it his fave and he had somewhat decent taste in movies, but this just didn't have that comedy feel to it. I walked away feeling as if I had watched a lifetime movie of the week.Jessica Tandy is a sweet old woman who has played in a handful of movies I like throughout the years. Stan Shaw is the man and I was glad to see him here although his role in this movie was rather boring.The Couch family was the best reason for watching the movie Gailard Sartain is just one of those 80's actors who always played the same silly character in most of his movies but he was always fun to watch. Kathy bates was doing one of her many 'out there' roles as she played the lonely in love Mrs Couch and I loved seeing her on this film.It is basically a movie where Kathy Bates character meets Jessica Tandy's character in an old folks home and is told a story about a girl and a boy and a best friend and that best friends abusive husband and about the kkk and fried green tomatoes and the whistle stop café.The story was told over numerous visits to the old folks home and the story bored me silly, I did as I mentioned above, love the parts with Kathy Bates in between.This movie wasn't funny really, but it was dramatic and if you're into the whole chick flick thing then go for it. Its one of those movies your grandparents would like. I am glad I watched it, but never wanna see it again.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies of all time!
reviews.content: In my life, I have not seen any movie that has moved me the way "Fried Green Tomatoes" did. There aren't many movies that can make me shed a tear, I regularly watch action movies and silly comedies, and I don't have much of a reputation of being a sappy person, and being a man, one has to have a tough guy facade, but somehow this movie really got to me. The first time I watched it was when I was about 8. I knew English at that time so I was able to watch it, and thank god for that. I shed my fair share of tears all through the movie, and almost out sobbed my mother and sisters (which is not an easy task!). I prefer not to tell anything about the story of the film, because it is better if you take it all on your own. Trust me! I only wanted to share with everyone what an impression the movie left in me...When I am old and gray I most likely will be pestering all the young people to go and watch it and get some culture!!! ;) :D hehe :P

This film has such a good story , don't expect break-neck action or violence , its 2hrs long , but it keeps you captured for that whole two hours , i've seen it more than once , still when i watched it again tonight i had to pause it every time i left the room , not wanting to miss a single frame , i'm a 33yr male and this film is so well screen-played and so well acted ( in every roll ) it just deserves to be seen , anyone who likes being told a good story and loves to indulge themselves into that story should not pass this one by , i think we should all stop by at the Whistle Stop Cafe at some point in our lives it may just enlighten us , one of the best , Daren

All I have to say is that this is one of the best movies ever made, and even though it is different than the book it still brings out the same meaning. I thought it brought out the best of the book and I also think the casters did an excellent job at choosing the characters. When I saw this movie the characters from the book jumped out at me. This movie is in every way shape and form a beyond excellent film. If you hate this movie you have a serious problem and should go seek professional help. Infinity thumbs way up! If I were part of the Oscars I would absolutely have this film win the majority of the awards. I know this may sound crazy, but I truly believe this film is better than The Titanic.

An exceptionally well written, directed and acted film. It deals with fundamental values as friendship, courage and love. It sounds a bit sassy and girly when you talk about it, really - but never the less, this movie really touches you. Thomas Newman's perfect original score adds the final touch to a truly moving piece of cinema. Highly recommendable!

This movie has it all,mystery, humor,tragedy, and drama. After 5 minutes I knew that Idgy Threadgood was a lesbian,although that was not acknowledged during those times, heck it still is not in some places in the deep south! I am glad I was not born during those days, the level of racism,that permeated those days is sickening!Sadly, there are folk TODAY, who would love to go back to those days! They hide behind
political affiliations and actually get elected to
HIGH office!

Beyond its content and everything else this film tells three stories in an intertwined way. A story in the present is tied to a story in the past is tied to a kind of child's tale or fable story that is told within. It is so masterfully set that watching this film is already a pleasure by merely admiring the applied techniques of story-telling.Even if you may not be too much attracted by the films theme or genre it is worth seeing it in order to enjoy what a good scripting can achieve in a film. I truly enjoyed watching it and the mere writing already makes this an all-time favorite on my movie list.Apart from this it contains an important message, a good chunk of both severity as well as humor and I think it is no spoiler to mention that this film might leave you with some sort of remaining mystery that the recipients will yet enjoy to solve for themselves.

reviews.review_title: Mindless movie about the Deep South enough said.
reviews.content: A movie set in the 50's about the deep south, and a family of Southeners... yeah you know where this is going.... a highly overate film. \

reviews.review_title: Somehow I wish I had some fried green tomatos, served hot!
reviews.content:
Really touching, great acting, beautiful story, excellent human sentiments and ideals.
Allow me one remark. They left Idgie/Ninny's luggage at the end, outside the demolished house!

I really want to write a book review seriously, but every time I look back at the movie and the original story, I will fall into endless memories and sorrow. Those who have passed away in the South, those good times that have passed away, like that plate The chilled fried green tomatoes can't describe its deliciousness when I regain my consciousness. Only by reminiscing the aftertaste in my mouth can I go back in time and go back to the leisurely lazy afternoon, aimlessly walking Enter the coffee shop in Steam Whistle Town and listen to the story of the duck and the lake.

Every time I have seen "Fried green tomatoes" so far (about 5 times by now), I could not marvel enough at the beautiful plot and characters. Thomas Newman (well-known for his fabulous score for "American Beauty") gives another example of his art: the music at the beginning of the film mirrors exactly the slight melancholy of this movie. I am sure you will enjoy the deeply moving story. Unbedingt ausleihen - rent it!

I never tire of this movie.  I can watch it again and again and I always find something new.  The entire cast is terrific, especially Kathy Bates, Jessica Tandy, Mary Louise Parker, and Mary Stuart Masterson, but even the smaller roles are played with depth and precision.

reviews.review_title: A blind rental selection that tops my chart
reviews.content: I can count on two fingers how many movies I have consciously chosen to see more than once (Blues Brothers being the other). This jewel has consistently been my response to "What is your favorite all-time movie?" In this day and age where sex, violence, drugs, and profanity are a must for a movie to attain high ratings, this one offers a wholesome and entertaining story (with admittedly subtle overtones regarding relationships)that can be viewed by the whole family without having to mute or fast forward every five minutes. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone who tires of the gratuitously offensive offerings of today's fare.

oh my lord. watching this movie during a difficult time in my life helped me get through it. watching kathy bates struggle through her own personal dilemmas, whatever it is resembling a mid-life crisis, and using the experimentation of new things to get through it really resonated with me. i have seen it now three times and liked it better and better each time. i wish there were more diversity in cultures and alternative lifestyles, and alos more backstory about the brother. other than that, i couldn't have asked for a more enlightening 2 hours. the actors were great, the writer was great and the images were great. if you haven't seen it find it and rent it.

reviews.review_title: Good for A Sunday Afternoon with Family
reviews.content: This film is about how people grow from nurturing relationships the same way land benefits from care and feeding. This film is so good for the soul. Set in rural southern America, this story beautifully and humorously illustrates relationships between many types of people, social levels and ages. Every aspect of this film was rich and completely enveloping. Kathy Bates is utterly charming portraying a woman who grows strong while listening to stories about another time. This film is not over sentimental, it is warm and pleasing and very human. Funny, sad at times, and so poignant, i am grateful to the filmmaker.

reviews.review_title: The definition of a heartstrings-tugging movie about life
reviews.content: Fried Green Tomatoes has no shame in being sappy and sentimental. But if you don't get hung up on that, it's really a sweet movie about reminiscing on the good and bad of life, where underneath everything the real story is about the people you love. Of course it helps that the movie is well-made and well-acted.

As a young man growing up in the Country of my home town of Hawkinsville Pulaski County Georgia, I had saw the movie in rental stores, however I was just never quite interested in watching a movie called Fried Green Tomatoes!!! However one night while watching TV with my family I was flicking through the Chanel's and came upon this very net resting movie that just so,happens to be..yes you guessed it...Fried Green Tomatoes!!! Well right here in the middle of my review I get a knock on my door, some guy tells me that he had just hit a little black dog out in front of my home, we live on a dirt road and people drive on it as if it were a damn Interstate Highway!!!! Sure enough it is my late fathers dog Buster!!! One of the last things my Daddy said was son look out for my dog!!! Now I feel really bad!!! He is not dead yet, he has his wits about him, just a bit loopy, but catching one of those full size Chevy Silverado's ain't good for a 4 pound dog!!! Anyway please pray for Buster!!!! Now back to the Movie review... As I began to watch this movie I just got more and more intertwined into the story!!! I couldn't tell who was more intrigued by Iggies story, me or Evelyne Couch. The story about Frank Bennett was so interesting!!! Heck there wasn't anything about the entire movie that Wasn't interesting!!!! The most interesting part of the entire movie was the fact that Frank Bennett's body was never found!!! And even more the reason WHY IT EAS NEVER FOUND!!!! Big George Put him on the grill and made BBQ out of him and they fed him to the guy from Georgia that was so stern to Iggies that he WAS THE LAW!!!! And you can't beat the law!!!! So to sum it up in a few words!!!! Fried Green Tomatoes is by far one of the best movies I ever saw, most important I. Was working with Georgia Power and happened upon this little Cafe out in Julliett Ga. And before I knew it I was sitting right in the middle of where one of my favorite movies was made..The Whistle Stop Cafe!!!!! You can't imagine my excitement and couldn't wait to tell my wife that I had sat and eat right there where the story played out!!! Now I'm gonna take my wife there to have some of those world famous FRIED GREEN TOMATOES!!!! And if you never watched this MASTERPIECE PLEASE DO!!!

reviews.review_title: I saw this when I was quite young...
reviews.content: ....I was born in 1986; do the math. I saw it when it was new. I loved it then, when I didn't fully understand all the themes, but it's my favorite movie of all time now that I'm a 33-year-old. I love a bunch of "chick flicks" including Steele Magnolias, Pretty Woman, Terms of Endearment, A League of Their Own, Sleepless In Seattle, and Pride and Prejudice. I'm also into superhero blockbusters, sci-fi & fantasy, straight dramas, thrillers and *some horror*, adult comedies, and Disney/Pixar family films. Fried Green Tomatoes is my all time favorite movie.

Fried Green Tomatoes was one of the most inspirational movies I've ever seen. My mother had me watch it with her, and the greatest thing about this movie is how it can make you laugh and make cry in a way like you truly know the characters. In other words the way the flashbacks are put together to show the closeness of Idgie and Ruth, allows you to get to know the two characters as if you were meeting them to be your friends, along with the spectacular acting of each and every character. For example, when Ruth got drunk I laughed as if I was there with her, when Idgie gave the canned goods to the needy I felt her caring as if I knew her since we were children, and when Ruth died and Idgie was crying, I cried as if I knew Ruth as well or even better than Idgie and I could feel the closeness of Idgie and Ruth throughout the entire movie. The Evelyn character and her whole part in the movie along with her life I think brought more comedy to the drama of the "good old days" of Idgie and Ruth's life part of the movie. Evelyn also brought a "breather" for the audience so they could think about what just happened with Idgie and/or Ruth. I could watch this movie over and over and I still laugh and cry my hardest.

Jessica Tandy received a nomination for Best Supporting Actress (and it was nominated for a Writing award), but Fried Green Tomatoes definitely should have received Best Picture for 1991. I will never get over the fact that "Silence of the Lambs" won while this fantastic movie wasn't even nominated! This movie is an absolute must-see.  Be on the look out for a quote that I've used many a time since. (It probably comes from the book the movie is written from.) It is so humorously true.  Imagine it spoken by a woman with a very thick, southern drawl:"Is there anything worse than a man who's sick?"

This is truly a good field they film that you were fall in love and you will not be disappointed I love that the characters I love everything about this movie I also love the relationship between the two women that shows what friendship is about and I love that the story has a really sweet story.

reviews.review_title: What binds Ruth and Idgie? . . . Love.
reviews.content: The book this movie is based on is a very difficult one to make into a cohesive movie, being that it travels back and forth in time and is told from many different points of view.  Taking that into consideration, I feel that an excellent job was done.  One of the more difficult tasks the filmmakers had to contend with was portraying the truth of Idgie's and Ruth's relationship while retaining the subtlety of the novel.  Part of the beauty of the movie for me is the fact that I knew that they were in love without anyone ever having to scream it into my face.  The four women in this movie are some of my favorite actresses and the portrayal of small town southern life is for the most part charming, but realistic in its portrayal of the racial and gender-related tensions that were present at the time. All in all, this is one of my favorite movies and is one that I can watch over and over again without getting bored.

My mind turns to mush when I write about movies that are simply perfect.And since this movie was an absolute masterpiece of garbage, my mind is unprecedentedly sharp.I heard about this movie after watching a Martha Stewart show in which she said to add tomatoes to a stew to make it taste good. But when I opened up my refrigerator and saw that all of my tomatoes were rotten and all green, I thought "eww, maybe I should throw these away..." But then Martha Stewart said "just make sure the tomatoes aren't green, like the movie Fried Green Tomatoes".So when I heard that, I thought "hmm, so maybe there is a use for 2-year old tomatoes" ... and I quickly went out to rent this movie. To my amazement and utter disgust, I found out that this movie had little-to-nothing to do with my old tomatoes. I took some paper and a pen to write down the recipe, but I seriously didn't get anything out of it.After the movie finished, I went home and thought "well, maybe the recipe just means that I am supposed to fry the tomato" ... so I went out and bought a deep frier from Bed, Bath, and Beyond for like $50 and put my tomato in there for about 10 minutes ... when it was finished, the skin was all hanging off of it and it smelled like a wet dog. But I figured that it must taste amazing if they made an entire movie based upon it. Needless to say, I was in the hospital for a week.So overall, this movie is very misleading and I didn't appreciate that. But I give it a 2 for effort.

reviews.review_title: Fried Green Tomatoes really works for me.
reviews.content: I really love this movie. I have no idea how many times I have seen it. It gets better every time. Fried Green Tomatoes may be the best "womans" movie ever made. It is about adult women whose friendship sustains and strengthens them. I love Jessica Tandy.Many movies are made about the friendships between men (the ever popular buddy movies). Many movies are made about romance and the relationships between men and women (chick flicks). However few movies are made about relationships among women and of those that are made, many are about the negative aspects of relationships. And finally, as mentioned by one of the other reviewers, it does not stress female relationships at the expense of the men in the film.Kathy Bates scores in this film as well.

reviews.review_title: Can't believe it only got 7.7 ratings
reviews.content: A fresh, lovely story, full of southern charm and heart. A movie about friendship (or is it?)and how it shapes our lives. But I'm a little disappointed it didn't go all along with the novel which is absolutely marvelous. All in all, it's a classic and so good.

This is one of my all-time favorite movies. I just love movies that have a great plot, great actors to make the movie, and a great soundtrack to set the mood. This is just that movie. 'Fried Green Tomatoes' is a good wholesome movie for the whole family to enjoy. This movie reminds us that love and friendship goes beyond race, age, and gender, and that both are endearing qualities that can withstand the test of time. This movie will make you laugh, cry, and get up and dance too!:) The late Jessica Tandy (Cocoon, Cocoon Returns, Batteries not Included) is one of my favorite actresses. She narrates this film in such a way that it makes you feel like she's your grandmother who has you seated in her lap while reading a phenomenal story. This is one to add to your collection, or re-rent every now and then.
It is a great movie that carries you from beginning to end, but if you did read the book you will be kind of disappointed at some parts.

reviews.review_title: Solid performances, not so sure about the rest...
reviews.content: I saw this movie a while ago, and thought it was enjoyable, but I had some issues with it as well. The leads did a good job, and the mood and scenery was atmospheric. Most of the characters were pretty one-dimensional though. And the really weird thing about this movie was the fate of the abusive husband, and especially Cathy Bates' reaction when hearing about it. "Oh, you got rid of his body through cannibalism? Hahahaha! Good job!" He was an abusive idiot, sure. But killing and eating him for it? Wow.The way I prefer to see this movie is as a macabre piece of southern Gothic thinly disguised as a feel-good chick flick.

reviews.review_title: Is there anyone in the South who's not a "colorful character"?
reviews.content: Well having now finally seen this, I have to say this isn't the type of movie I'd been imagining over the last 25 years or so; I'd thought it would be some Southern "romantic comedy" with the four leading ladies all in the same household at the same time having various heart-warming hi-jinks; instead it's these two parallel (fairly "serious") stories about 50 years apart. I guess the earlier story was the more personally compelling for me, since it was the one with the luminous Mary-Louise Parker, whom I've been watching in "Weeds" on my cable service and it was fascinating to see this younger version of her doing her native accent (she's from South Carolina). It's fascinating how she mixes passivity with latent ferocity, like an angel carrying a switchblade knife or something. When she casually threatens to kill her abusive husband without raising her soft voice but with a little demented gleam appearing in her eyes, it's scary. It's been said "Acting is reacting," and I don't know a better reactor. She also benefits from a much "fuller" story situation, with all the other characters (I didn't even recognize old Cicely Tyson) and sobering subplots involving the KKK and domestic abuse and a murder trial (although even this veers towards camp) etc. (I've never been a fan of Mary Stuart Masterson, but she seems well cast here.) I did think that Ruth's getting sick and dying felt "rushed" ---"Wait, she has cancer? When did that happen?" ---but the actual death scene with the single camera shot was maybe the best thing in the movie. (That's what happens when people die of "natural causes," it's usually not "dramatic," they just slip away.) The "modern" story, by contrast, was mostly between Kathy Bates and Jessica Tandy, who STILL had time to do four more movies after this before finally dying. (I saw her in "Dragonwyck" from 1946 but I forget what she looked like young. I'll have to catch her in something else.) The modern story felt more by-the-numbers, but the amazing Kathy Bates (who completely stole the most recent season of "American Horror Story") can bring even the tritest part (in this case the meek housewife getting "uppity") to life; she and Tandy have some great exchanges about vaginas and hormones. I was a little annoyed at the "mysterious" ending, with the suggestion that Tandy's character was possibly the older version of the Masterson character; it reminds me of a line from "Detective Story" from 1950: "Twelve years ago I threw my radio out the window; you know why? 'Cause I hate mysteries!" But at least Tandy didn't turn out to be a goddamned ghost or something—or so I'm presuming..Anyway I'm glad I finally got to see it; my only regret is that Ruth's scumbag husband didn't suffer more when he died. Don't even get me started on the topic of abusive males, it just drives me absolutely bat-crap, reflects badly on all us male types By the way there's a certain plot point that seems borrowed both from "Soylent Green" and "Sweeney Todd," not to mention the "Texas Chainsaw" series, and they all leave me wondering: So how were the inedible bits disposed of?

reviews.review_title: Why Does Everyone Think This Is A Lesbian Movie?
reviews.content: I find it very interesting, if not hilarious, that many people are rushing to judgment on the lesbian issue. Saying that the two characters are lesbians is like saying Batman is "queer cinema" (the Village Voice's term, not mine), simply because Bruce Wayne is single, rich, neat, well-groomed, drives a nice car, has an extensive wardrobe and hangs around beautiful women.And if they are lesbians, I doubt that it went beyond deep friendship, since the story takes place in depression era Alabama in a very small town. Back then, you didn't even utter the word "lesbian," much less act on it.If you want to see two lesbians, you will.

reviews.review_title: It'll make you laugh, it'll make you cry.
reviews.content: This is my all time favorite movie. One goes through all the motions, from laughing to crying, the scenery and harmony of the intermingling storylines are enchanting. Mary Stuart Masterson and Marie-Louise Parker are absolutely wonderful together and Kathy Bates is excellent as usual.

reviews.review_title: Wonderful film but a bit rocky near the end.
reviews.content:
The first 2/3 of this movie is quite great. The music is strange in the beginning and not memorable at all, but it gets much better at the end. It also has tremendous acting for a 90s film.
