The characters are all fleshed out to the hairs on their arms. They glow with emotion and reason.The movie also challenges racism and sexism in a well constructed structure. It even very subtly brings up sexuality, although it's never stated and only is hinted at.The film is about a story about telling a story. I didn't care much for the story that takes place in the present, but I understand why they wanted it. Other than that, the only thing else I disliked was the twist at the end. I won't spoil it, but don't get your hopes up. It builds up this tension and then abandons it. They then choose a random answer to it that seems way out of character.Acting:
Value: 8/10.

reviews.review_title: One of the best films ever made
reviews.content: Fried green tomatoes is without doubt one of finest movies ever to come out of Hollywood. The script is top notch, the cast superb and the production lush and expensive. I've seen it maybe a dozen times now and it never gets old. The gay elements are obviously very subtle considering the era it was made but still present and very poinient. The tackling of racism and the realities of the American south blend beautifully with the overall story. Jessica Tandy is mesmerising, Kathy Bates superb as usual, Mary Stuart Masterson and MLP are fantastic. The film is realistic, engaging and funny when it needs to be. One from the golden age of cinema.

reviews.review_title: I loved the movie, until I read the novel
reviews.content: I was quite disappointed in the movie after reading the novel.  It was disappointing that Idgie's and Ruth's real relationship never came through in the movie.  They were obviously lesbian lovers, which the movie swayed away from.  It was quite annoying, and left me unsatisfied.  Also, in the book Ruth is not Buddy's ex-girlfriend.

I love this movie, I could watch it a hundred times and never get tired of it. It has some sad parts in it that make you want to cry, but its still the best movie. I love how they have two totally differnt storylines in one movie. I dont see that very often. I love the story of idgie, both mary's played the part excellant. Kathy Bates is so great in this movie. It really shows at the end how things never stay the same and you should always remember the not to take things in your life for granted.I also liked how they made the character of idgie totally change her views on life and become a much more loving person. I could go on an on about it, but if you havent seen it then you are missing out, if you've seen it then im sure your like me and want to see it over and over again.

I wanted to stop the movie as train approached, as you could see a tragic lost of a young life. A lesson as why you should never cross a train track. It showed him getting clear of the train, yet he still died. Guess it gave the viewers a reason to watch the next few minutes to see if he survived.
It was a compelling and engaging movie. I'm not certain if I watched it at the time, but really enjoyed the story within a story.
It had a happy ending. So few movies these days do.
A great storyline...kinda slow and slightly boring, but great if you're into that past-present storytelling. Sad beginning, but that's okay.

Along with many others, I have just seen FGT for the first time, and I was enthralled! The authenticity of the characters, the setting, cinematography, and the plot kept me captivated. There was one small error, however, that caught my attention. At the end, when Frank Bennett was being served up to the sheriff from Georgia, the continuity director seems to have forgotten that he didn't show up at the Whistle Stop until several days after Frank disappeared. I'm sure all the "special sauce" was gone by then. Needless to say, this did little to dampen my appreciation of the movie, and I look forward to seeing it many more times.
A wonderful lesbian love story. Two woman befriending one another and then falling in love. It's beautiful and sweet and depicts a true loving relationship. Highly recommend to everyone.

reviews.review_title: I felt like I was there, in the south, having fun and sorrow with them.The actresses and actors were the best.
reviews.content: This was a movie I like to see over and over again. This movie gives me good feelings, of closeness and love, lots of love, love between friends, and closeness of family.

reviews.review_title: My childhood was marked by this movie
reviews.content: This is a great story. Outstanding acting. Beautiful storytelling. Love it! Prepare the tissues. It grapples with the woes of the past and the baggage that it brings with it. Past meets the present.. Chris O'Donnell is a sight to see even if it break your heart later.Fried green tomatoes is really one of those movies that stick with you and becomes timeless and unforgettable.Don't expect the best special effects, this is not that kind of movie, this is a movie in which storytelling is at its best. Be aware of the occasional racial insensitive situation, it is after all, a depiction of the Jim Crow South.

If you haven't seen the movie or read the book... there may be spoilers in my post...
This movie was exceptionally good. The Book was exceptionally good. In fact if you read the book and watch the movie you may actually think that these are two interpretations of the same story. Well... I did.. Kinda.. My opinion is that "Ninny" was not Idgie. But infact "Ninny" herself. I believe that Ninny placed the jar of honey and the sentimental note on Ruth's grave as a token of love from both her and Idgie. In the movie it shows that everyone loved Ruth. My favorite parts in the movie were about Ruth and Idgie... I did not particularly care for the scenes of Evelyn... gaining her womanly strength.. they were good.. but.. not as powerful as Ruth and Idgie's scenes.The book however... was Excellent. Yes, there are some hints that Idgie and Ruth were deeply in love with each other. "Ruth and Idgies boy" was one clue and the whole yelling scene in the book when Ruth leaves was a major tip off.... *LOL*.All in all.... 9 stars out of ten!

reviews.review_title: This movie is a bittersweet tale of love and loyalty
reviews.content: This story is a poignant tale of love and loss and it surrounds the friendship of two young women from the past as told to another woman in the future by the surviving friend. The story includes the developing relationship between the women sharing this story in their own twist of fate. It also shows the growing independence of the woman who is being told this story. She develops into a strong person in her own right. This is the female version of the loving friendship between David and Jonathan in the Bible. This kind of intimacy in friendship is not that rare among women. There is nothing to suggest a sexual relationship except in the mind of someone who is perverted in their thinking. If this was written about two men you might assume something immoral. Men are not usually as close in their relationships as women.

When I was 17, my mom introduced me to 4 classic films.Fried Green Tomatoes, Driving Miss Daisy, Steel Magnolias, and Terms of Endearment.They all are unique and mean a lot to a lot of people.But FGT really resonated and stuck with me. It struck a cord.I adore period peices taking place in the '30's in the South. I love the fashion, music, and most importantly, the togetherness unfortunately not felt in modern times.It is a wholesome and heartwarming film. It's so because there are tough times portrayed. Death, abuse, alcoholism, murder, court and changing times. Which makes all the tender moments so much sweeter!This film came out in 1991. It's based upon the novel from 1987. It is accurate generally. There are some differences I didn't think were necessary.Implying that Ninny and Idgie were one in the same was a stupid move, tbh. They're so different! And why imply it??The time these events took place in was condensed, but because it's a 2hour movie, it's forgivable.There were parts left out of the movie. More backstory about Big George and his family.And of course, the biggest implication of all...the fact that Ruth and Idgie were essentially married. The L word is never said in the book, but they hug and caress and kiss each other. They're referred to as a couple and as Stump's parents. They share a room.I know it was 91, but I don't know why these things couldn't have been portrayed. They were in other smaller films. There doesn't have to be pornography in order to heavily imply two people are together. But I digress.It's a wonderful film I've seen hundreds of times since then. I've read the book 2 or 3 times, read fan fiction, written fan fiction, and gifted the book to multiple people. Anyone that I've recommended this film/book to has been pleasantly surprised and thoroughly enjoyed it. From anime lovers to metal heads.

All I got out of the film was Kathy Bates' character whining and nagging her husband for wanting to relax and watch the Braves' game after a hard day's work. What a horrible way to live.I did like Jessica Tandy's character, but then she is a great actress, and would be excellent in just about anything.But every time Bates' character started another complaining, nagging rant about something, all I could think was "please put a muzzle on her". That would have made the film much more enjoyable.But I must disagree with the other comments - this is, without a doubt, a chick flick.
I have to watch this movie over and over again. It's funny and sad and touching.

reviews.review_title: Fried Green Tomatoes: A Must See
reviews.content:
Fried Green Tomatoes is a film with themes of love, family, friendship, the need to care for others, and women empowerment. The film is set in 1920s Alabama, which gives you a taste of the racial tension back then and shows the good-hearted nature of the main characters, Idgie Threadgoode and Ruth Jamison. The film shows the beauty of unlikely friendships that turn into family, not by blood, but by heart. Lastly the film gives us strong lead women characters and the struggle a middle-aged woman, named Evelyn Couch, has with her marriage as she is going through her midlife crisis. Through the film Evelyn finds her self-worth, with the help of a sweet old lady, and the power of being female. 
This movie will make you laugh, cry, rage, and everything in-between. By the time it's over you will be making fried green tomatoes and yelling "Towanda!".

I have to admit, this has to be my favorite movie of all time. This one of the few movies where you feel really engaged in the story line, almost as if you were in the movie. It always leaves me in tears because it reminds me of a small town I used to visit when I was a young child and how over time they slowly disappear. Soundtrack is perfect as well. Overall very moving and encouraging with some added comedy, a movie that most could resonate with and enjoy!

Truly great Southern film. I love how they don't bash Christianity. Jessica Tandy, who was actually English and had a successful career on the London stage and a less successful one as Mrs Jack Hawkins, is back in the South she visited first when she created the role of Blanche DuBois in A Streetcar Named Desire on Broadway in 1947, albeit this time around Alabama as opposed to Louisiana and is a joy as the frame narrator enchanting Kathy Bates with her reminiscences of life in the 20s and 30s; a life that embraced laughter, tears and a murder trial. It's all there, the small, sleepy town, the benign Blacks, the obligatory KKK, the eponymous cafe which is the focal point of the town but at the heart of it all a wonderful and enduring friendship to rival that in Il Postino. Virtual unknowns Mary-Louise Parker and Mary Stuart Masterson hold their own and more against the veteran Tandy and well-established Bates but all the cast turn in exceptional work. Unashamedly Art House the number of positive comments on this very site are testimony that it found its audience. This will enhance any DVD collection.
Decent acting but this winding tale about nothing in particular is a bit tedious.

What a feminist propaganda. They even reveal, that it is not a problem to kill a man and cook him as a barbecue. And the character of Idgie was not sympathetic to me, but annoying.The only good thing in this movie is the presentation of theWhat a feminist propaganda. They even reveal, that it is not a problem to kill a man and cook him as a barbecue. And the character of Idgie was not sympathetic to me, but annoying.The only good thing in this movie is the presentation of the old southern US life.

Fannie Flagg's prized novel gets the Hollywood treatment, thanks in no small part to Flagg herself — who co-adapted her own work for the screen — and a veritable who's who of feminine acting icons. "Fried Green Tomatoes" is a gratifying blendFannie Flagg's prized novel gets the Hollywood treatment, thanks in no small part to Flagg herself — who co-adapted her own work for the screen — and a veritable who's who of feminine acting icons. "Fried Green Tomatoes" is a gratifying blend of Southern Gothic stylings and the winsome spirit of a woman who believed wholeheartedly in countering homophobia and misogyny with earnest will and good humor. It's honestly kind of amazing to me how much queerness Flagg managed to sneak past audiences in the late 80's and early 90's. She really was breaking ground with this work. And the structure built on that ground, whether you personally identify with the subtext or not, still makes for a tender and enjoyable stay in what feels like a community you've been a part of for a substantive amount of time.
It’s challenging to create a movie that holds true to the corresponding book. This movie succeeds in all the right ways.
Emotionally riveting, but intriguingly captivating, Fried Green Tomatoes is a thought-provoking coming of age film.

meta_summary: A housewife who is unhappy with her life befriends an old lady in a nursing home and is enthralled by the tales she tells of people she used to know.
